TITLE.P: Fully Managed Digital Interview Recording System (DIR)

SHORT_DESCR.P: Greater Manchester Combined Authority (GMCA) as the contracting authority is[SW3] seeking for a suitable service provider to provide a Fully Managed Digital Interview Recording System (DIR) including Hardware, Software, Storage and Service. Software and/or Storage may be cloud based or within the authority’s data centres. Key requirements are:
— A fully managed, end-to-end digital recording solution including all hardware, software, storage and managed service for support and maintenance.
— Digitally record audio only and audio/visual interviews.
— Fixed, portable and hand-held recording devices, microphones and cameras (with at least one PTZ).
— Recording from fixed and hand-held recorders shall be uploaded to a central repository.
— Recording from portable devices shall allow a copy of the interview to be burned to a disk or uploaded to a central repository.

Greater Manchester Combined Authority (GMCA), acting as the Contracting Authority for Greater Manchester Police (GMP), has issued this Prior Information Notice (PIN) to advertise this opportunity to the open market and seek expressions of interest from suppliers that may wish to take part in future associated tenders.

As part of the market engagement exercise interested bidders may be invited to present their solution to GMP W/C 21st May 2018 (subject to amendment), this will allow GMP to explore the market place and gain market information to better prepare the procurement process.

Please include Company details, emails, and telephone number. Following the expiry of the PIN, a short market engagement questionnaire may be sent out to all parties who expressed an interest, allowing GMP to gather feedback from the market to assist in the specification.
This is a PIN notice- No tender documents have been issued at this stage.

INFO_ADD.P: To participate, interested parties (including SMEs, social enterprises, voluntary or community organisation) must be registered on Bluelight with up-to-date contact details to include company name and E mail.
Key requirements are:
— A fully managed, end-to-end digital recording solution including all hardware, software, storage and managed service for support and maintenance.
— Digitally record audio only and audio/visual interviews.
— Fixed, portable and hand-held recording devices, microphones and cameras (with at least one PTZ).
— Recording from fixed and hand-held recorders shall be uploaded to a central repository.
— Recording from portable devices shall allow a copy of the interview to be burned to a disk or uploaded to a central repository.
— Operating screen for the user to operate the fixed and portable recorders.
— Allow the user to input metadata relating to the type of interview and the interviewee (and their representatives).
— Where the interviewee is in custody, the DIR solution shall import metadata from GMP's custody system, and export start and end date and time of the interview to the custody system.
— Configured so that it can be assessed to prove that no tampering of the recording is possible during the recording.

— Configured so that audio and audio/visual recordings must be created using open, non-proprietary standard formats. It must also be possible to convert these formats to other formats to allow files to be played by a wide audience using freely available software and consumer CD and DVD players.
— Allow the user to be able to insert bookmarks at key points of interest in the interview file during recording or after the interview has been recorded.
— Allow the user to play 3rd party evidence whilst the interview is recording.
— Allow downstream and live stream monitoring to authorised users.
— Have a facility to create a CD or DVD from digital interview files which is playable on domestic media players.
— Allow users to play back any audio and video recordings, once or multiple times.
— Allow users to transcribe recorded interviews, using headphones, from any desktop computer connected to the force network.
— Provide a search facility that will allow authorised staff to locate recordings by inputting a combination of metadata.
— Have a method for setting a retention period for each file in accordance with the Code of Practice on the Management of Police Information (MoPI), 2005.
— Configured so that it will only allow the Force's system administrators to delete interview files.
— Provide a secure external access solution to publish recordings so that authorised third parties can access them.
— Retain audit data for 6 years and six months from the date of deletion of the interview recording.
— Test and training system which will operate on a separate database to the live version.
— The DIR solution will be provided as a fully managed service.
